comments:
This problem arises if you declare a volatile property on an abstract class, 
declaring the volatile method abstract and implementing it in subclasses.  
XMIResourceImpl emits (incorrectly) a value for that volatile property when 
serializing subclass instances, with the result that it cannot deserialize the 
resulting XMI file, because the following exception is thrown:

(My temporary workaround is to remove the offending volatile property from the 
model.)

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: The feature 'type' is not a valid

Adrian, unless a feature is transient, it will be serialized, so this sounds to
be working as expected.  Volatile only affects the implementation, i.e.,
generated verses hand written, and has no other impact.

traces.message: The feature 'type' is not a valid  changeable feature
